1153.title: Looking For More

choices: Alissa Ravenwing Awakens
The Garrosh'ar Slaughterhouse
11531.content:
"Another fine mess, huh old girl?" Sky Admiral Rogers sighed deeply as she rubbed the railing of The Skyfire. The most illustrious airship in the entirety of the Alliance fleet, The Skyfire had already quite the history before falling into the hands of Admiral Rogers. Present at the downfall of Deathwing himself and nearly a Horde conflicts before it, The Skyfire had become a beacon for Alliance soldiers in even the dire of battles, and Admiral Rogers certainly felt that she was in such a position. Surrounded on all ends by a deep impenetrable mist, Rogers and the men and women of the Skyfire had been hopelessly lost for nearly a week now. Handpicked by King Wrynn himself, the crew of the Skyfire were on a mission of the utmost importance, tasked with the retrieval of "The White Pawn". In actuality, Prince Anduin Wrynn who had become shipwrecked in an earlier expedition to a newly emerged continent in the South Seas.

"Admiral Rogers!" shouted a runty gnome from the far deck, diminutive even by the standards of his own people. "You have to come see this."

"First mate, report!"

"Admiral..." the gnome pointed out in front of him. A translucent glow had begun to appear in the mist and as The Skyfire chugged closer, it became readily more apparent what it was, a raging fire in the far distance. The gnome pulled out a spyglass as he peered into the distance, twisting the focus as the image before became more readily apparent. It was a shipwrecked Horde scout, stranded amongst a cluster of jagged rocks illuminated in the mists only by the burning inferno that raged even against the crashing tides. "None of the intell suggested that the Horde would be present!"

Admiral Rogers was taken aback. "Details were scant, but I can't pretend I'm surpris-" The Admiral stopped mid-sentence, as the mist immediately began to clear almost as if it had never been present at all. The Admiral gazed upon the landscape as it so suddenly came into focus. It was unlike anything she had ever seen, a serene forest of sparkling emerald that seemed to stretch on for as far as the eye could see. To go from nearly a week of nothing, but a listless fog to such majesty in a moment's notice was enough to distract the Admiral from what lay right before her feet.

The sound of coarse shouting voices broke her from her trance. It turned out that the Horde encampment below them was just as surprised by the sudden emergence of the Airship as they were.

"First mate; battle stations!!" the Admiral bellowed, as the crew of the Skyfire scurried to the gun turrets, attempting to mow down any Horde that made it to the goblin flak cannons below. The battle raged for what seemed to be only a moment, the Skyfire reigned havoc upon the unprepared denizens of the make-shift forward camps, but it ended as quickly as it started as a goblin engineer managed to set off a dragon rocket at the big broad target. The goblin missile hit with the force of a cataclysm, the entire airship careened violently in response as it struggled to keep altitude. The Admiral rushed to the engine room, barely managing to keep her balance as the Skyfire lurched violently, throwing any crewman to close to the railing overboard. The Admiral arrived just in time to see her engineers hard at work, trying to keep the engine running by any means necessary. "We need to cool it down, it's going critical" one of the engineers shouted, as the engine roared, steam erupting from nearly every safety gauge attached. "It's going to blow!!"

The Admiral deftly dived to her feet, barely managing to stay aboard as the backdraft from the explosion blew the stern of the ship clear off. Rogers watched in horror as crew mates plummeted to a watery death, swept clean off their feet by the force of the explosion. Rogers took a tight grip of the railing, as pulled herself up to take one last look at the carnage below her. She managed to spot the one thing that gave her hope in her final moments the sign of a rampaging Worgen tearing an entire grunt platoon apart limb from limb in a brutal blood frenzy.

"Ha, that almost makes it worth it."
11531.title: A Thickening Mist

choices: Alissa destroys the logging operation and retrieves the mysterious scroll.
Alissa finds the camp already beset by a Worgen Berserker.
115311.content:
A lone figure on an empty beach, Alissa Ravenwing stirred from unconsciousness as she grasped one arm out weakly, clawing at the sand as she pulled herself up. The tides crashing down on her and soaked from inch to inch, Alissa fought to keep consciousness as she struggled to remember the events that had transpired. A champion of the Cataclysm Campaigns, and a former Warden of the Cenarion Circle, Alissa had been requested to accompany SI:7 during a personal audience with the High King himself. She had thought herself dead when The Skyfire crashed into this newfound land, but obviously it seemed that fate still had plans from her.

Alissa surveyed the beach, finding little, but assorted driftwood and flotsam from the crashed gunship. Her belongings had vanished from as far as she could tell, and the majority of her equipment with it. "Hmph..." Alissa grunted as she walked down the beach barefoot, her toes sinking into the wet sand. "Couldn't have even spared my boots?" she whined to no one in particular. It was of no particular matter to her though, a staff and a pair of boots were of no real use when you could transform into a hulking bear at a moment's notice.

Making her way into the forest, Alissa was at awe of the serene beauty that made up this strange new land. Untainted by it's inhabitants, Jade Forest was a stark reminder of the beauty that had once stretched throughout all of Northern Kalimdor. Before the Horde began it's mass logging campaign in Ashenvale, tearing down large chunks of Lissa's century year old home. Before the Burning Legion tainted what was now known to be Felwood. Before the Cataclysm which had torn Darkshore asunder. For all of it's majesty, this strange emerald forest had managed only to open old wounds.

Taking the guise of a panther, Alissa skulked through the forest hoping to come across any survivors of the Skyfire. Alissa wandered for hours before a familiar sound caught her attention. The sound of goblin buzzsaws whirling and axes plunging into the trees. Alissa's blood boiled at the very idea of it, with every swing of the axe, painful memories of Lissa's beloved homeland bubbled to the surface. Every felled tree, every inch of the forest that had been set ablaze, the very death of Cenarius. It all triggered in that moment. Without a moment's hesitation, Alissa sprinted towards the cacophony with a lust for blood in her heart.

********

"Zug Zug!"

The taskmaster looked down at the Peon that had been so bold as to address her, a look of contempt in her eyes. "What is it worm?"

"Um...me no be meaning to be interrupting big important bosslady, but..." The Peon reached into his pack, before removing an object that had been wrapped tightly in a poorly-stitched blanket.

"This better be worth my time..." she said, spitting on the ground.

The peon removed the blanket, revealing an object that positively beamed in the sunlight. It was a scroll, but nothing like she had ever seen before. Stitched in what almost seemed to be pure gold, and held together by onyx handles, the scroll was written in a language like she had never seen. Each word was gilded with ruby, making the words seem almost as if they had been handed down by the gods themselves. "We found it while cutting wood, thought bosslady might think it important. Maybe peons get extra food ration today??" he asked earnestly.

The taskmaster's stood stone face as she glared down at the peon. "Get back to work, dog." The peon scurried off terrified with nary another word. "Surrounded on all sides by idiots" she muttered, as she wrapped the scroll up and handed it off to one of the goblins in the surrounding area. "Hold onto this, until we can get a local to translate it. Understood?"

********

The peon worker wandered back to his station meekly, heartbroken that he'd have to be the one to break the news to his comrades that their would be no extra rations tonight for a job well done. He was positive that "bosslady" would not only be happy to see that they had uncovered a priceless artifact, but would reward their initiative with a hearty extra helping of orcish gruel. He pondered long about all the ways he had went wrong in his approach, before his thoughts were broken. The sound of rustling leaves and twigs snapping in the distance caught his attention as he went to investigate, uncertain what could be causing such a ruckus. "Huh..." he said aloud. "Anybody out the-"

Alissa immediately leaped out from the clearing, pouncing upon the hapless peon, tearing his throat with her claws. Alissa quickly surveyed the logging camp, it was small. Freshly set up. It wouldn't take long before she brought the entire thing operation crashing down on in flames.

"Easy prey..."
115311.title: Alissa Ravenwing Awakens

choices: The worgen is carrying Sky Admiral Rogers and she's badly injured
The worgen has an unresponsive dwarf cradled under his arm
1153111.content:
In days passed, the brilliant pink leaves of the glade’s trees would rustle lightly in breezes blown in from the sea. The natives would spend afternoons in the soft grass below the boughs of the trees watching them dance in the wind. Today, what natives remained stained the grass red and embraced it with their bellies instead of their backs. The trees jerked and shuddered, oozing sap onto the stained ground as axes were sunk into their trunks. The orcs may have well have been sinking those tools into Alissa.

From the edge of the grove a lithe panther exploded through what small brush separated her from the first peon she felled. The first pair of peons assailing the ancient trees were on the ground and bleeding profusely before anyone could so much as shout in confusion. Alissa pounced from the hemorrhaged peons, bloodied paws landing with little noise. Yells of alarm rippled through-out the small camp and a half-dozen or so peons hefted their chipped axes to defend themselves or abandoned kodo-hide tents before they could be fully erected. In the back of the hastily assembled camp a pair of goblins playing cards were interrupted, the female taking advantage of her partner’s distraction by sweeping the anted gold pieces into her arms and bolting to the safety of the forest, only to be followed by a furious comrade moments later with the scroll leaning against their table forgotten. What caught Alissa’s eye in particular was a sturdy orc woman, turning from a collection of restrained prisoners with a look of malice etched upon her face.

Alissa snarled, leaping sideways to evade a hastily swung peon lumber ax. The muscles in her hind legs coiled and released as she didn’t so much jump on but over the orc. With a fluid motion she dug her claws into her flesh, launching herself clear of the lacerated peon and onto the one behind him. She landed with fangs bared and clasped down on his throat. She leapt again, tearing chunks of flesh as she did so. An axe intended for her back imbedded itself in the chest of the downed peon; Alissa raked her claws across the chest of the weapon’s owner before slamming her hard skull into the open wound and shoving the orc off his feet. Blood splattered onto the short purple hairs of her head, further adding to the mess of red staining her snout. Her ears twitched, her head swiveling in response to a throaty war cry. The stony ork woman thundered towards Alissa slicing down with a massive sword. The druid squirmed in her attempts to rush forward. The howling blade bit flesh, drawing thin ribbons of red from a slice running down the druid’s flank. Alissa pivoted on nimble paws that were swelling larger by the second. Her thin form ballooned with layers of muscle and fur as a deadly predator yielded to an unstoppable behemoth. The bear charged, a glancing sword blow shaving only hair off her thick shoulder, smashing directly into the orc’s armored gut. The taskmaster grunted and stumbled, digging her heels into the ground in an attempt to stop her backwards listing. Alissa bellowed a gutteral roar, drowning out a high-pitched voice shouting in the distance. She hefted a claw and swiped it forward. The impact dented the task master’s armor and forced the orc to the ground. Alissa shifted her weight and slammed the female once again with enough force to make her tumble a few feet. She heard armor crunching and the faint drag of a sword sliding through soil. The voice returned, more insistent this time. The druid lifted her claw one more time, snarling at the orc staring defiantly up at her through a haze of pain.

"Stop!"

Alissa hesitated, her claw hitching in mid swipe. She gazed at the orc before her, matching a returned stare that was full of mirrored hatred, anger, and confusion.

“No more! Please.” The soft female voice pleaded as a sob nearly made her speech inaudible. Alissa pinned the orc to the ground with a heavy paw before turning to face to the origin of the sound. A small gnome in tattered, oil-stained coveralls with pink pigtails was staring at her with wide water-rimmed blue eyes. Tears pattered softly against the ground. The druid sighed, her form slimming as she returned to her full height, her bare lavender foot pressing against the downed taskmaster. Alissa beseeched the trees of this grove, requesting they contain her prisoner as she released the others. The grove responded, gnarled roots burst from the ground and ensnared the orc in their sturdy grip. She struggled against them, grunting in effort. Alissa awkwardly padded over to the crying gnome, who had since hidden her face behind pink bangs. The gnome was separated from the remainder of the prisoners, all Pandaren and most of them cubs. Alissa winced with each step she took, pain lancing through her wounded thigh. She swallowed, unsure how to deal with an emotionally distraught civilian. She attempted to clean some of the blood from her face before clearing her throat, “Are you alright?”

What looked up at her was not the distraught civilian that she expected. The small gnome produced an intense look with furrowed brow, her eyes dry and narrow. “Are you stupid?” The gnome hissed in a low whisper.

“I…I’m sorry?” Alissa reeled from the small woman, her eyes wide.

“The Skyfire is grounded, maybe even destroyed. Its crew is scattered and we’ve only encountered one horde settlement.” She spoke as though this was an obvious fact. “And you want to kill the first horde leader we find without even trying to get information out of her?”

“She’s just the leash holder of a ring of lumber-chopping thugs, why wou-“

“Intelligence gathering has to start somewhere.” The gnome interrupted, fidgeting against her bonds. “Everyone wants to get to the boss right away and always forgets that you need to shake down the menials first to know where to go.”

Alissa moved to assist her, but the gnome stood. Strands of sliced rope fell to the ground and she slipped a small gnomish pocket knife back into the band of her belt. “At the very least, she can give us an idea if there are more of these camps and where they may be.” The gnome turned her attention to Alissa, casting her gaze up and down the night elf. “So, you must be the druid the King stuck with us. Ravenwing right?”

“That’s correct.” Alissa gave a nod, rubbing the rest of the blood from her face. “Though seeing as it’s just us, Alissa is fine.”

The gnome shrugged non-committedly, “If we’re being informal you might as well just call me Miki. Now, Alissa, please help the rest of the prisoners while I search this camp for anything worth taking with us.”

“Very well.” Alissa gave the gnome a side-long glance. Miki Thermocog had been quiet on the journey over; Alissa had only run into her a few times. The druid had taken her to be part of the engineering team that kept the ponderous ship moving. Alissa shook her head, tending to the bewildered natives and properly securing the injured orc taskmaster. From what the natives told her, there was a village nearby. The horde had attempted to seek harborage there a few days ago, but flew into a rage when denied. They assaulted the village, taking children and field workers prisoner before setting up in the village’s fields to chop down trees. The adult prisoners offered to lead the two there as thanks for rescuing them and extended an invitation to stay and have a drink. It was at this point Miki cut in and asked if anyone there could translate a scroll. Apparently the only thing of interest she could find was an ornate scroll with onyx handles and jeweled lettering that was obviously not written in orcish script and that these natives could not read. Upon assurances that there was a lore walker within Paw’don village, Miki agreed to join the natives in returning to their home. Alissa hauled the injured and bound orc over her shoulders. Her form shifted resulting in the orc being draped across the back of a tall, sturdy deer.

The pandaren natives led them to a quaint village nestled in the hills of the glade. Short walls surrounded it and simple one story buildings with teal tiled roofs sat on raised hills behind the walls. A small crowd of villagers clamored at the arrival of their loved ones. Parents ran forward to scoop up their children and hold them tight. Alissa’s chest swelled as she watched the natives re-unite with those the horde took from them. A male pandaren with a wide brimmed sunhat and a staff that had a bottle hanging from it approached the two alliance women with a smile on his face. Miki turned to regard him but a dull hush had descended on the crowd and suffocated the joyous mood. They followed the trail of gazes to the road, noticing a figured padding up the smooth stone path. It was a worgen, black fur stained almost entirely blood red. The loose metal plates strapped to his hulking form clanked as he hefted a limp individual cradled under his right arm. Soft orange eyes smoldered with iris flitting about to examine the crowd of pandaren, his attentive ears were nicked and scarred. He approached the gate, stopping shy of the two guards holding steady to either side. He regarded them with quick glances before looking at the other two alliance members. He spoke with a deep voice, refined voice tinged with the faint grumble characteristic of worgen.

“Ladies,” He gave a courteous nod of his head, “we need a medic.”
1153111.title: Cat Fight

choices: A Lorewalker's Story: Lien-Hua and the Sha of Gluttony
11531112.content:
"I can be of assistance." Alissa said, immediately stepping forward. "Truth be told, I gravitate more towards the wrath of nature, rather than it's nuturing aspect, but any port in a storm." She immediately knelt down, getting a closer look at the the unconscious figure that been slumped against the stonewall. It was a female dwarf, garbed in white vestments, her red hair twisted into twin braids that fell lifelessly against her chest. The former white brilliance of her robes had been obscured by a concerning amount of dirt and dried blood, it seems that she had been left to die for hours before she had been found.

Alissa instantly recognized her, as she pulled the woman's hair back, revealing her face. It was Ingrid Thunderstout, one of the many adventurers that had accompanied her on the Skyfire. Boisterous, kind hearted, and shockingly indulgent for one of the Light's Faith. Alissa struggled to remember a single time that the pudgy woman, even for one of her race, wasn't proudly waving around a drumstick and a full pint of ale. Alissa was never much for companions, but it was hard to ignore Ingrid when she went to such lengths to make her presence known.

"Figures." Miki said as she ducked beneath Alissa, getting a closer look at the unconscious priest. "When I was debriefed before the mission, I was led to believe that she's one helluva healer. She would certainly be useful healing, uh, herself."

Alissa glanced at the gnome, fighting back the urge to roll her eyes. "Please step aside while I attend to her." she said as she pushed the gnome aside. Alissa looked around, her eyes perking up as she spotted a small pile of leaves that had scattered among the ground. Snatching them up, she began to gently whisper into bundle of leaves, her voice calm and nurturing as she beckoned for nature's call. The leaves responded in turn, a small green light emanated from them, quickly becoming brighter and brighter as the leaves lost form. Alissa pressed the healing energy into Ingrid's lacerations, the open wounds slowly began closing. She moved from wound to wound, the Dwarf's color returning as she was brought further away from death. Alissa stood, addressing the rest of the group. "She's stabilized, though I advise we get her some rest before we stir her awake."

"Good," Miki said, as she turned her attention to the fearsome Worgen that towered over her, the Warrior still drenched in blood. "Aaron Gregory Culverstone I presume?" The Worgen nodded in turn. "Ah." Miki continued. "Former Noble turned Gilnean Revolutionary. Warrior, Gentlemen, with a bit of a problem with his temper."

"Now, now if that ain't the hat trick. You're three for three!" Aaron said with a snicker, his voice drenched in a thick Gilnean accent. "Now I don't recall for a moment sharing more than a word with you above the Skyfire, you plan on telling me how you seem to know quite so much about me and our sleeping beauty in the corner over there?"

"SI:7." Miki said proudly, the crevices of her mouth turning into a slight smile just at the sound of her station. "Let's just say, we didn't just bring a bunch of numskulls straight out of Abbeyshire on a mission of this importance. I know everything about you stretching back to your grandparents. Now if we're done measuring dicks, we have some ground to cover. We're stranded big time, in a strange new land, with the Horde breathing down our neck on every side. The Skyfire is a wreck, and as far as I can tell, we may possibly be the only survivors." Miki looked out into the horizon, the smoke of the logging camp still visible in the distance. "The Horde have already set up camp, and if we have any hope of rooting them out and finding the Prince. At least the locals are friendly. Our best lead right now is that Orc, but I get the feeling that she's not quite up to talking right now.."

Alissa interjected, as she reached for her belt and retrieved the scroll that they had confiscated. "What about this scroll? I believe we were told that a Lorewalker in town might have some answers to it's origins?"

Aaron immediately froze at the sight of the scroll, as his eyes contracted into a fierce glare. A swirl of what seemed to be a black viscous liquid danced around the edges of the scroll for a brief moment before retreating back into the parchment. "You all see that? Bit of witchcraft right there if you ask me. I ain't having none of this."

Miki raised an eyebrow. "Are you serious? Cut the nonsense, this is our best lead at the moment. Even if it turns up to be a dead end, the locals might at least be gracious to have it back."

"I can feel nothing but darkness from this scroll, ruffles my fur just the sight of it." Aaron snarled, as he pushed past the rest of the group heading back into town. "If you're gonna push on like a couple of half-wits playing with strange magic you ain't even got the slightest clue about, then be my guest. Come find me when you're done."

"Idiot..." Miki rolled her eyes, as she redrew her attention to the unconscious dwarf slumped over the ground. "Well, if you're up for heaving our friend around, shall we proceed Alissa?"
11531112.title: Worgens and Dwarves and Scrolls! Oh my!

choices: Ingrid awakens; the Sha of Gluttony's influence makes itself known.
The party turns their attention to their Orc captive.
115311121.content:
Alissa grunted and groaned as she heaved the hefty dwarf through the doors leading to the Lorewalker Library. "She's...heavier than she looks." she moaned to Miki, the small gnome fought to stifle a giggle in return.

More than a simple library, the Lorewalker outpost was bursting at the seams with artifacts of bygone eras. Each wall was adorned with elaborate scrolls, each scrawled with characters from a language they had never seen before, each adorned with gold and valuable gems. Elaborate ornate weaponry hung from the ceilings, magnificent in their construction and far more elegant than anything they had seen the local guard wield. Fearsome dog statues hung over the entrance to the library, and even more noticeable were the mountains of books. Stuffed into every single available shelf, and then some, it seemed that the Lorewalkers had even begun stacking them on the ground, huge piles of books threatening to reach the ceiling. The two adventurers had never seen anything quite like it.

A single solitary Pandaren greeted them as they entered, her hair in buns highlighted by a single green streak. She welcomed them warmly as she lit a stick of incense, it's smoke filling the room with a relaxing aroma. "Greetings, travelers from beyond the mist."

Alissa gingerly placed Ingrid on a bench in the corner, as she went to greet the Lorewalker.

"Well met, friend." Alissa said with a courteous bow. "I am Alissa Ravenwing and my companion is Miki Thermocog. Thank you for the pleasure of this meeting." Miki bowed in turn.

"The pleasure is all mine. I am Lorewalker Suchong. What assistance may I offer you?"

Alissa retrieved the scroll from her waistband, offering it to the Lorewalker. The Lorewalker unraveled the scroll silently skimming it as a look of fret began to unfold over her gentle demeanor. Without a word, she silently wrapped the scroll back up before walking to the other side of the room. She sifted through a large pile of tomes before arriving at one, scooping it up in one arm as she returned to the confused duo.

"Tell me travelers. What do you know of the Sha?" the concern in her voice was barely palatable.

"The what-now?" Miki asked quizzically.

The Lorewalker turned her back to the two adventurers, her attention fixated on the plumes of smoke that arose from her incense burner. Tearing a page from the tome she retrieved, she tore the page to shreds before delicately placing them in a small divot in the burner. Grabbing the incense stick, she touched the flame to the torn page. The flame was weak at first before rapidly growing out of control. The page burned to cinders, and from the smoke arose fantastic images of enormous black and white beasts. Hulking centipede like creatures adorned with malevolent twisted faces. Miki and Alissa both took a hesitant step back, unnerved by the monstrous beings.

"The Sha..." Suchong began as the room went oddly dark, save the stage which was brightly illuminated by the strange flame that had been lit. "The physical manifestation of the negative emotions that plague all who walk this world. Fear, Hatred, Anger, Violence, Doubt, and Despair, they are the outward embodiment of the blackness that inhabits the deepest corner of every man, woman, and child. With every harsh word, with every thrown punch, their essence gathers, growing stronger, as they bide their time until their power erupts corrupting every being in it's wake."

With a flick of her wrist, Suchong fanned the flames, the monstrous beings disappeared, quickly replaced by a single Sha. Smaller in size, and bloated at all ends, the Sha seemed to be an almost twisted parody of the beasts that preceded it. "And then there are the lesser Sha. Greed, Envy, Lust, and the most insidious of the four, Gluttony. Though their power is far more limited make no mistake travelers that they are dangerous none-the-less." Suchong unraveled the scroll, reading from it, the scroll itself was a series of haikus that told the story of Lien-Hua Sunspark and the first emergence of the Sha of Gluttony.

                   "Ten centuries past
                   A hungering wicked sha
                   A courageous monk."

                   "The peaks of Kun-Lai
                   A battle waged valiantly
                   For the good of all."

                   "Gluttonous and fat
                   His hedonism rained upon
                   The naive locals."

                   "Rounder than pumpkins
                   Heavier than the black ox
                   The villagers grew fat"

                   "Lien-Hua opposed
                   The decadent influence
                   That gripped the village"

                   "Lien-Hua did starve
                   To deny the sha's hunger
                   A cunning trap set."

                   "The sha approached her
                   Why deny your hunger girl?
                   Feast now, feast forever."

                   "With a solemn vow.
                   Her fast uninterrupted
                   She weakened the Sha."

                   "And then one fall day.
                   Lien-Hua's fast gave loose.
                   And she did succumb."

                   "The sha was bound-
                   Lien-Hua's hunger was his
                   and so too did he pass"

"Tragic." Alissa said, "To sacrifice everything in the face of such a corrupting influence..."

"Though Lien-Hua's demise was pitiable, she has stood up in the annals of our history as a beacon of self-sacrifice. Along with the lessons of the beloved Emperor Shaohao she taught us the need for self-restraint and benevolence."

"Lies, all lies..." a voice whispered, it's source unseen by Alissa and Miki. The voice lacked any hint of displacement or direction. As if the words had been uttered in a vacuum of stale air. Alissa and Miki scanned the room with wide eyes, baffled by the origin of the voice.

"Is something the matter?" Suchong asked, puzzled.

"You didn't hear that?" They both answered in unison. Suchong shrugged. Suchong wished the pair well, as Alissa heaved Ingrid up again on their way out of the temple. Richer in Pandaren culture, but still mystified in terms of the next step of their journey Alissa and Miki left the temple slightly dejected. Aaron had made his way to the local inn and the three women followed suit. Alissa wasn't quite sure what their next step was, but there was one thing she knew for certain. She was famished.
115311121.title: A History Lesson

choices: Aaron gets his drink
The girls order their food
1153111211.content:
Loud, that’s how he’d describe the inn. Full of natives laughing and talking, the sound of clinking glasses, and the sizzling of food in iron woks. The scent of sautéed meats mingled with hints of smoke and alcohol. Fire crackled in the hearth and torches blazed in their sconces, casting a warm light throughout the wooden building. Dozens of pandaren villagers rested at circular wooden tables, sitting on sturdy wooden stools and partaking in veritable feats of freshly cooked meals and cold ale. Aaron drew his gaze back, inhaling deeply. The worgen maneuvered his way to the hearth situated in the back. He walked with light step, feeling a bit cold after taking a dip in a nearby creek to clean up. A warm fire would definitely do him good. He set down near the fire, laying a pack loaded with clean armor and weapons by his side.

He closed his eyes, reveling in the warmth washing over his fur. ‘We’re done cocked here it seems,’ Aaron flared his nostrils, exhaling roughly ‘Left with nothing but a spanner in the works and the sad remnants of a gormless rescue team. Need to pull it together somehow or we’re right screwed.’

“Ah, there you are.” A haggard voice croaked, maybe a few feet from Aaron’s right. His ear flicked and he shifted his head, opening an eye. A pair of pandaren stood behind him, one wearing weathered gray clothing and leaning on a bamboo staff. The other stood tall and was dressed in dark leathers, a wide brimmed hat, and a loose belt cinched with a medallion of a tiger’s face. Most noticeable was a spaulder of a roaring tiger on his right shoulder. Most of his face was obscured by a crimson mask, but his judgmental gaze was harshly analyzing the worgen. Aaron’s eyes narrowed, answering the newcomer’s challenge. His fiery orange eyes locked defiantly with the fierce yellows of the Pandaren.
“Lord Zhu, this is one of the outsiders that saved our village.” The mayor spoke awkwardly. Sunke Khang if Aaron remembered correctly. He spoke with Khang briefly while on the way to wash up.

Khang shuffled, eyes shifting between the frowning worgen and the masked pandaren. “The villagers speak of how you entered,” Zhu finally spoke, even his voice pointed and harsh, “coated from head to paw in blood. You would do well to be careful about what kind of energy you bring to our lands.”
“If you’re worried about me going off my trolley and tearing your people limb from limb, don’t.” Aaron snorted, turning back to the fire “I’ve gotten good at controlling it.”
“You call slaughtering an entire encampment of people in the most visceral fashion possible control?” It was Zhu’s turn to scoff.
“You’re charitable to call the horde ‘people’. You’re better off without them; trust me that lot ruins everything they touch.”
Aaron could feel Zhu’s stare boring into the back of his head. “We can defend ourselves from this horde stranger and we can defend ourselves from you. We will not participate in this bloodbath you look to bring with you. We will not tolerate your genocidal war on our shores.”
“Then it’s your lucky day mate,” Aaron turned to glower at Zhu once again, “because we’re here on a ‘peaceful rescue mission’.” He snapped, reciting the mission statement they were given on the Skyfire before it was split in two.
“You have a twisted notion of peace, outsider.” Zhu remarked, turning away from the worgen. Aaron heard them take several steps, likely enough for Zhu to assume they would not be heard over the din of the inn. But Zhu did not count on the berserker’s sharp hearing. “You can give these outsiders quarter at your discretion Khang, but do not get wrapped up in their conflict. They bring nothing but their race-war here. I must go; there are others that have landed in the north.”
“White Tiger watch over you, Lord Zhu.” The Mayor bowed. The sound of footsteps signaled Zhu’s retreat. Khang sighed, approaching Aaron once more. “You and your friends are welcome to stay in our village, it is the least we could do. But I implore you; please take his words to heart.”
“Thank you for your hospitality, Mayor.” Aaron responded flatly, not turning from the fire. Khang gave a resigned nod, disguising a frown and turning to leave the inn. Aaron spent the next few minutes in relative silence, tuning out the ruckus of the bar and focusing on the raging fire in front of him. It was nice; he hadn’t had time to relax since before they left Stormwind. Conditions aboard the Skyfire had been cramped and loud and it had proved impossible to get comfortable.

After an unknown amount of time an insistent prodding in his shoulder stirred Aaron from his trance. There was a voice prattling off with the poking, speaking curtly. “AG, hey AG. Stop staring at the fire we have work to do.” The gnomish imp was pressing two fingers into his shoulder blades.
“Don’t call me AG.” Aaron grumbled, pushing himself up. The others were assembled behind him with Alissa sitting at a table with the dwarven priest, trying to help her through the wake-up process. The orc was tied down in the corner and Miki was staring at him, arms crossed. He followed her over to the table, lowering himself onto the short stool and bowing his legs to scoot close. He shot Miki an expectant glance, folding his hands on the table. “So, find anything worth noting in that daemon scroll of yours?”
The gnome waved her hand dismissively, “just a history lesson about a monk that sacrificed herself to stop a Sha.” She glanced at Aaron noticing his cocked eyebrow, “Physical manifestations of negative emotions of the people here. This one happened to be about a lesser Sha, the Sha of Gluttony.”
“I told you that was no good business.” He frowned, “Thing’s probably cursed too.”
“Only thing we were cursed with was useless information and folk tales.” Miki grumbled, looking at Ingrid as she pulled her head off the table and groaned. “Only one lead left now.” She winced, her sentence punctuated by a low grumble as she put a hand on her stomach. “Ugh, but first we should get something to eat. I feel like I haven’t eaten in days.”
Aaron nodded, turning to the druid sitting across from him. “How’s our patient doing?”
“Out of it, though she seems to be-“
“Both me head an’ gut are pounding.” Ingrid cut off Alissa, holding her head in her hands. “Auch, just gimme a pint and a bite and I’ll be fine.”
The Worgen shook his head, “Might as well stay the night. A good rest and a nice supper will fix both of those problems.” His ears twitched, registering another rumble. He angled an eyebrow at Alissa, the night elf shrugging her shoulders sheepishly in response. Aaron rolled his eyes, “guess we’re getting food to go around then. Well, since we’re shacking up for the night I’m going to get a drink.” He pushed himself from the table, padding through the tavern towards the bar.

The girls didn’t wait long before he left to flag down a waitress. Cries of ‘that sounds good’ and ‘I would like one of those’ reached his ears and he swore he heard one of them say ‘why don’t we just order everything?’ before their voices were lost amongst laughter and clinking mugs.
1153111211.title: A Cold Welcome

choices: Aaron makes it back to the table
11531112111.content:
Aaron slid onto one of the short stools near the bar; he ran his hands along sturdy wood of the counter. It was worn with ages of sliding mugs and steins across it and stained by splotches of greasy food complimented by thin rings left behind by countless beverages. The barkeep was an older native woman with a pony tail; she turned to Aaron as he sat down. The woman beamed at him, pronouncing a few wrinkles near her mouth. “What can I do for you?”

Aaron returned the smile briefly, thankful she wasn’t put off by the maw full of sharp teeth, “Stout please, darkest you have.”
She gave a nod, spinning on her heels to a shelf packed with a mind numbing variety of bottles. She deftly yanked a bottle out of the stack without disturbing the others around it and produced a glass. With little pomp she filled the glass and set it down on the counter within a few second, sliding it towards the Worgen. Her smile grew as Aaron’s eyes widened and he slowly fished out a few coins and set them down on the counter. “Enjoy,” She bowed her head and turned to satisfy other patrons, pulling and re-shelving bottles with an artistic grace.

A soft giggle drew his attention from the display; a female pandaren had taken the seat next to him. She wore a smile, like many of the natives here did. Her fur was auburn and white, a mask of russet colour surrounded her green eyes. She brushed a lock of green hair out of her face, a streak distinctly different from the brown of her hair, some of which pulled back into a braided pony tail and the rest cascading down her back. She wore dull red leather armor, with a bit of flab sticking out around the fastening buckles. Her belly rested on her lap. He could tell she was a bit bigger than the other natives of this village, if only because her thighs covered most of the stool. “You look like you’ve never been to a bar before.”

Aaron huffed, taking a sip of his drink. A faint hint of the chocolaty liquid lingered on his tongue. His snout crinkled, eventually falling into a frown. ‘Augh, they call this a stout?’
“Something wrong?” The pandaren cocked her head to one side. “It’s not actually your first time is it? Because I have some good starting drinks-“
“No.” He waved a hand at her, “Sweeter than I was expecting, was hoping for something with a bit more bite.”
“If you want something bitter you should try the Kafa. I-”
“The what?” Aaron glanced at her.
She had turned around to fish in the pack sitting next to her. “-could probably find something that would work in the meantime. Bitter right?” She shot her gaze up to meet his.
“Yes?” He raised an eyebrow, watching her curiously.

The pandaren only hummed in acknowledgement, rummaging for a few seconds before producing a steel flask and proceeding to shove it in the Worgen’s face. Aaron cautiously took it from her grasp. “Tell me what you think of that and we’ll go from there.”
He took a sip, mulling it around for a few seconds before swallowing. Bitter, strong, and thick yet still smooth, this was much closer to what he was looking for. He curled his lips and nodded, “That’s more my speed. Thank you Miss…” He trailed off, narrowing his eyes slightly. ‘I really need to be more wary of accepting strange flasks in the future.’

“Jun Cloudstep.” She beamed at him, “Glad you like it. Luckily the ingredients for that are close to town so I can make more in a hurry.”
“You’d run off just to make more of this for me?” His gaze switched between the flask and her face.
“I’m a brew master. Making beer for people is what I do.” She shrugged, “Everyone deserves to have a good time and a better drink.”
“I shouldn’t be surprised a profession like that exists here.” He remarked flatly, casting his gaze about the tavern.
“Oh there are plenty of us,” she began, “a few really famous ones with specialty brews and everything. I know brew master Blanche personally and you won’t believe what-” Aaron paused in his scan as he noticed a combination of waiters and kitchen staff carrying what appeared to be a massive roasted bird that had to be as big as his torso into the dining area. His eyes narrowed, darting to more pandaren clad in aprons carrying out bowls of noodles, stir fries, soups, and platters of rolls and grilled fish along with a sealed keg and a fistful of mugs. They all appeared to be heading to the same destination. His gaze snapped back to the pandaren next to him, who was waving her arms animatedly “-and lightning is striking every few seconds and she’s screaming at us to put the keg fires out, so we-“.

“Could you excuse me for one moment?” Aaron was standing before he was finished asking, weaving through the crowd on the way back to the girls; he prayed that he had misheard their intention to order a sample of the entire inn’s food stock.
11531112111.title: And a warm hearth

choices: Morning comes and the girls wake up to some changes
Jun and Aaron hunt their fugative
115311121111.content:
The Worgen shoved his way through the crowd, stopping at the edge of the table. Wide eyes surveyed the recently delivered roast bird, surrounded by platters of steaming food and tankards full of local brews. He blinked, his gaze turning to the trio of women surrounding the feast fit for twenty five. Two had wasted no time, gleefully devouring the small bowls of noodles and vegetables in seconds. Alissa had seemed to master the use of the tiny wooden sticks the pandaren eat with in record time. Miki had simply resorted to using a fork built into her army knife. Ingrid wasn’t even eating. A tall mug of beer occupied both hands and a spot in her bosom. She took sips out of each one with a practiced precision only a dwarf could have while drunkenly slurring out a Khaz Modan bar shanty. He frowned, eyes running over his compatriot’s disturbingly blank faces as his newest ‘friend’ caught up with him.

“Whoa, you guys know how to throw a party.” She remarked, looking over the jovial Dwarf “Mind if I join in?”
Ingrid spouted off something completely unintelligible to Aaron's ears, but the Brewmaster took this as an invitation to join. Jun nimbly slid into the last seat at the table and snapped the leg off of the bird, filled a stein, and pulled a noodle bowl towards her. “To new friends!” She said cheerily, raising her mug and downing it in one long swig.

Aaron approached the table slowly, acting as if they might eat him next. Up close he could see that most their faces had gone slightly pale. While he could never tell Night Elf skill color, he noticed the lack of red in the gnome’s and dwarf’s faces. Their eyes were dilated and expressions blank, locked on the table. The warrior’s frown deepened as he swept his glance to where their orc captive was, only to find a few strands of torn rope.

In a single motion Aaron had swept Miki up by the shirt with a snarl, a furious orange glow creeping into his eyes and lupine ears flat against his skull. “By the light Miki, did that crash scatter your damned marbles? Where the hell is the orc?” His growling shout boomed through the inn, echoing over the clanking of glasses and dinner conversations. The dangling gnome did not respond, instead reaching feebly for the food left behind on the table. Aaron’s frown turned into a scowl and he shook the rogue violently, “Damnit Miki, that was our last lead!”
That seemed to get through to her. Miki glanced around numbly, as if she was suffering from shell shock. Her head lulled to the side. “The… the orc’s gone? Well go find her AG. I’ll catch up when I’ve dealt with this gnawing hunger.” She rubbed her slightly distended gut with one hand and grabbed for her abandoned fork with the other.

Aaron couldn’t disguise the look of disgust on his face. He let the gnome drop and watched her scramble back to her forcibly abandoned dishes; he looked around the table at the vacant looks of his allied soldiers, the grease and sauce staining their faces. Ingrid had somehow worked a bowl of soup into the mix and her face was a mess of broth and ale. He stopped at Jun, noticing the contented smile on her face and the glisten in her eye as she savored the large roasted bird she was eating. “Well, I won’t be chasing my quarry alone. Jun!” He shouted. The Brewmaster paused, looking at him with her mouth closed around her second drumstick. “You really want to help?” He waited for her to nod before continuing. “Then saddle up, we had a fugitive to catch.” He took a step towards the door when he heard her emit a muffled huff, causing Aaron to roll his eyes “I’ll buy you a few pints to make up for it.”
“That’s more like it.” She swallowed and swept up her sturdy bamboo staff. She weaved around the table to his side, and was on his heels. The two left the warmth of the inn, the locals more than willing to make room for him after the show he just put on. Not like the furious warrior noticed anyway.

If the three women noticed Aaron leave, they made no indication of it. Through serving after serving, they continued to eat. They devoured plates of succulent pig, bird, and tiger along with their beds of rice and even the garnish. Bowls filled with noodles were slurped and swallowed to join the rest of the feast in their guts. Brews, water melon, steamed fish, fresh dumplings, no food lasted long on the table and the brew was imbibed with even greater haste. It was a grand banquet of all Pandaria had to offer, and it would not last the hour. Their purpose existed on this table, the solution to the gnawing hunger plaguing their bodies and thoughts. It was there in every chunk of bird or beast Miki slathered in spicy and tangy sauce, in every steamed dumpling packed with crab that she devoured in one gulp. It was there with Alissa, who still managed to pointedly ignore the dead animals on the table to cram as much wok friend vegetables and noodles into her mouth as she could slurp up, washing down each mouthful with a refreshing gulp of airy brew that never seemed to run out. It was there with Ingrid, whose mastery of the drinking form had won over the attention of many pandaren as they attempted to emulate her three mug stance as if it was a martial art. They paused to cheer when the dwarf kept balance with her dips for soup bowls, offering applause as she swept them up in her mouth and drained the delicious contents without the use of her mug filled hands. The three fed their gluttony, clothes pressing tight as they ate well into the night.
115311121111.title: Furious Feasting

choices: New quest: The cursed mansion!

11532.content:
Here's a freshly picked crew of three adventurous ladies, eager to start their new lives!

First up is Falindrah Arrowsong, the former sentinel. She's the most experienced of the three, adept with a glaive and bow, it's good to have her around. Sometimes seen as uptight, the early retiree of the Darnasus guard is bound by honor and loyalty. She's friendly and caring, if a bit brash at times. Her dark violet skin is accented by her starry white hair. She's trimmed and muscled for sure, comfortable among the trees.

Ianah Lightseer: powerful and sarcastic mage. She doesn't lack in the humor department, even with her slightly bored demeanor. Ianah knows she's powerful, and she's not humble about it. She aims to make a name for herself and claim what she deserves. Her sense of humor can sometimes be annoying, but overall welcome among the group (well, maybe not with Falindrah as much). Her skin is very dark, a rare trait among her people, but still common enough to not be outlandish. Her bright white eyes stick out in contrast from her otherwise all dark tone (including her black hair).

Adienna Lioncrest, a human of noble birth that decided to cast it off in favor of earning it herself. She's a priest in nature, able to use the light for healing, or shadowmagic for smiting. She's kind of heart and willing to help any in need. Somewhat innocent at first, she grew to adapt in the harsh world. Tougher than she used to be, her aim is to prove her personal worth without the aid of her rich family.

The group is quite fresh and haven't experienced more than a few quests. Though they're bound to at least grow in one way or another by the end of this story... whether it be one of them, or all of them.

Another responses until Gora sees two ogres coming down. One being more simple minded one headed and one wearing regal robes and two heads.

"Durr we eat her already?" One headed ogre looks upon the higher ranking magi. "No you moron! Go back to your guardpost. I will handle this for now." Good news for you is, You don't end up in Slag Mines as slave but you have the honor to become feast for Gorian Empire."

Gora was speechless, she always believed to perish in glorious battle, not getting captured by hungry savage ogres of Draenor. "A far better fate don't you agree? No need to work you to the bone and I believe woman like you would be dangerous with a pickaxe." Ogre mocks the warrior who roars in rage at him.

"My people will come looking for me you double headed pig!" Gora roars but a scared thought also fills her mind, if she was the only survivor from the ogre ambush does anyone realize that she is missing?

"Let's get to business." Two headed magi looks upon helpless orc who tries in vain to avoid getting the hose attached on her mouth. With the hose in place Goblin starts the pump and she is being force fed by some strong thick liquid. Cora can't spit it out so she has to accept it.

Few hours passes while Cora was getting dizzy and in pain from the constant feeding her sixpack has turned into nice potbelly hanging over her panties and her muscular features has turned more softer.

Van'Tsu was a Witchdoctor for the Darkspear, she healed and aided her people for many years, but recently, she's taken to the Streets, to aid those in need
who aren't her own. She sold her services for a reasonable price, and it did fairly well.

One day, she was at the local Apothecary for some cheap reagents, when she found a loose flyer nearby.
The Iron Belly Contest! Do you think you have what it takes to stuff your stomach to it's limits, and farther, for the sweet reward of Gold? This Thursday, down at Bilgewater Harbor, come and show off your amazing appetite and put that gut to use! 30,000 gold grand prize!


Van'tsu was very interested, "Wit' dat kinda cash, I could get bettah Reagents foah me spells, instead o' dese crappeh ones..." The Forsaken glared at her, "I'm right here, you know..." Van'tsu looks behind her, and when she notices the evil glare given off by the shopkeep, she giggles and responds, "..No offense." "I don't need your pity. This order is costing extra..." Van'tsu sighs, and pays the Forsaken. She leaves, and heads back to her hut in the Valley of Wisdom.

Van'tsu looks through her spellbooks, searching for a Hex, Spell or anything that could help her in the competition. She finally finds one, and finds out that it's...

Ven'tsu finds this spell to be extremely useful, grabs the necessities for the Ritual, and practices it on herself. A blast of light blinds her for not more than a few seconds, she coughs away some of the smoke, and looks around.

The Ingredients were gone, which means that the spell most likely worked. When she wondered what was supposed to be different, she felt a rumbling in her stomach. "Oooh, I be needin' some grub..." She then grabs some Leftover Boar Meat she had from last night, and finishes. "Woah, dat spell be really powahful. I don' feel full at all, an' dat was a very fillin' boar befoah." Her stomach rumbles again, and she grabs some more food, and stuffs it down her gullet. "I really shouldn't be doin' dis. I know dis only be da spell, but... I jus' be so hungry!"
She rushes around, and devours all the food within her hut. Her belly now had a noticeable bump, and it made the pants she wore underneath her robe feel tighter.
"Oooh... me stomach be so full... yet I be not feelin' it..." She groans, her stomach is giving very mixed messages. One side wants her to stop, but the other wants her to keep stuffing herself with more food. She considers it, and decides...

She got up, and rushed to the nearest Meat Vendor. She ordered the biggest Plainstrider Leg they could offer, ran home, and she hastily ate it.
At this moment, she felt her pants beginning to rip and tear. She looked inside the Spellbook she kept on her, and realized a side-effect to the spell, "Warning: It is recommended you do not eat over 200 pounds of food while under the influence of this spell, or else you may lose all control over your eating, and reversal will be impossible."
Worrying a bit, she checked her weight on a Goblin-made Scale. She remembered she originally weight around 175, but now she was around 350 pounds. Thankfully, this was just under 200 pounds of food. But she was still a bit chubby, she would deal with that later.

She reversed the spell, and tucked away the spell for later. In the meantime, she would simply wait until the competition...
